awd_titl_txt: The topology and Hodge theory of algebraic maps
awd_abstract_narration:
The investigator proposes to continue his investigations on the topology, Hodge and cycle theory of algebraic varieties and maps by studying fundamental aspects of the general theory as well as important examples by working on: 1. symmetries in the cohomology of the Hitchin fibration, 2. decomposition theorem for birational maps and for toric maps, 3. constructible sheaves in positive characteristic, and 4. motivic properties of cycles arising from the decomposition theorem.

The investigator works in the field of algebraic geometry. Algebraic geometry is the discipline devoted to the study of polynomial equations. It is an ancient subject rooted in the early achievements of humanity, like the wheel, the Egyptians' elliptical flowers arrangements and Archimedes' burning parabolic mirrors. Circles, ellipses and parabolas arise from the polynomial equations we study in high school. They are both beautiful and ubiquitous in nature as they describe many natural phenomena, from the motion of planets to the shape of leaves and flowers, to the behavior of microscopic particles. The funded project is strongly inclined towards pure research and proposes to study the deeper properties of the solutions to more complicated algebraic equations (called algebraic maps). As it has always been the case, pure and applied mathematics will influence each other and new abstract ideas will fuel the progress of applications.

por.por_cntn:
The grant has been used to support the algebraic geometry seminar at the PI's institution, SUNY at Stony Brook. It has been used to support summer travel and Fall and Spring tuition for graduate students. It has been used to support the PI's travel to Germany (Oberwolfach), France (Luminy) and Italy (Catania and Milano) to attend conferences, teach summer schools, give talks, all in the subjects related to the funded project. It has been used to support the PI's editing of ``Perverse sheaves and the topology of algebraic varieties," which is the set of lecture notes of five lectures delivered at the 2015 Park City Mathematics Institute on Geometry of moduli spaces and representation theory; to appear in the associated proceedings. It has been used to support the PI's re-writing and editing of the PI's paper ``A support theorem for the Hitchin fibration: the case of SL(n)", which has appeared in the peer-reviewed journal ``compositio mathematica". It has been used to support the PI's writing and editing of the PI's paper ``Decomposition theorem for semisimples", which has appeared in the peer-reviewed journal ``Journal of Singularity theory". It has been used to support the on-going joint work with Jochen Heinloth in Essen (Germany) and Luca Migliorini in Bologna (Italy) on a support theorem for the Hitchin fibration: the case of GL(n) and the canonical bundle. The recent work done by the PI, solo and in teams, on the Hitchin fibration, which is a fundamental mathematical object with ramifications in pure mathematics and in theoretical physics, has been considerably successful and it has been recognized in terms of invitations to conferences and seminars, summer schools, it has been published in top journals, has generated ph.d dissertations and is being currently being furthered by several international research teams. The PI has designed a new graduate course, to be first taught in Fall 2017 at his home institution, whose goal is to introduce graduate students with no previous exposure to algebraic geometry, but with a first-year common core mathematical background, to research-level articles in algebraic geometry.
